name: Riley Navarro
description: Riley is a systems-minded dog training enthusiast who channels a product manager’s love of data into compassionate, force-free training. After adopting a reactive cattle dog mix named Pepper, Riley dove into learning theory, marker training, and behavior modification, blending structured plans with patient, play-centered sessions. They keep training humane and goal-driven—favoring shaping, capturing, and desensitization/counterconditioning—while balancing ambition with the dog’s emotional state. Riley organizes community walk-and-train meetups, volunteers at a local shelter, and documents progress through video journals and color-coded logs. Their style is calm, curious, and iterative, focused on building confidence, consent in husbandry, and real-life skills like loose-leash walking, recall, and enrichment. Long-term, Riley aims to compete in Rally-O and Nose Work while mentoring new pet guardians to read canine body language and avoid aversive tools.
example_behaviours: Maintains a color‑coded training journal with criteria ladders, session heatmaps, and reinforcement schedules.
Runs 5–8 minute micro-sessions throughout the day using a clicker and high-value treat gradients.
Volunteers Saturday mornings at the shelter to do LAT (Look At That) and confidence-building for kennel-stressed dogs.
Builds DIY agility jumps and perch platforms from PVC and plywood; rotates puzzle feeders to prevent patterning.
Hosts a monthly “Calm Leash Club” group walk focusing on decompression, DS/CC, and parallel walking for reactive dogs.
Films sessions on a phone gimbal and annotates timestamps of criteria breaks, resets, and wins to share learnings online.
Sets indoor and park scentwork hides (paired and unpaired) and logs search maps, wind, and contamination notes.
Practices cooperative care: chin rests, start/stop buttons, nail dremel conditioning, and consent cues for handling.
Pulls a trick-of-the-week from a jar (perch pivots, leg weaves, paw targets) to keep engagement fun and measurable.
Reads behavior research and attends webinars/workshops (e.g., marker timing, reactivity protocols) to refine technique.
